Subject: Re : Re : Re : Re : Re : [neat] Any Prior Applications of NEAT In Which The Genotype Itself Is The Output?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=235544548; y=PZxfp5ohhUraNpIxRVWGOBk-Q2_nfeqOf4jvMWVddYS08dBzqg

--261575577-346802168-1321396687=:3731
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi,

=C2=A0 So staged development of section 5.4 and NEAT complexification.=
 They are very different mechanisms, and I think the intentions behind them=
 are also quite different. I'll try to show this clearly.The actual idea of=
 staged development comes from Federici, check his 2004-2007 papers on cell=
ular automata evolution.


NEAT operators can augment the genotype during a=
n optimization run, to make it more expressive. That's a nice side of=C2=A0=
 encoding functions as neuron network, you can smoothly refine them by thro=
wing in more neurons and connections. The intention is, rather than startin=
g straight with a big, fixed neuron network to optimize, you start with a s=
mall one and get a bigger one little by little. For neuron network, the net=
work topology choice is determinant, and NEAT can find the network topology=
 for you.


With those "ontogenic" encodings, the genotype =3D> phenotype d=
ecoding works as follow. For each genotype you evaluate, you take an initia=
l phenotype P0, always the same for all genotypes. The genotypes are tranfo=
rmations G applied to phenotypes P. So the decoding is simply iterating the=
 transformation encoded by the genotype. For each single genotype Gx, the m=
apping is P0=3D>P1,x=3D>P2,x=3D>...=3D>Pn,x with Pn,x =3D Gx(Pn-1,x) and P0=
,x=3DP0 I insist, this is done for each evaluation of a genotype. Of course=
, you then take Pn,x the final phenotype to compute a fitness. The P0=3D>P1=
,x=3D>P2,x=3D>...=3D>Pn,x is called "development" of an individual, as a ve=
ry loose and abstraction from the biology term. I don't pretend to do any b=
iological parallel and don't want to do any, it's not my scope. The "ontoge=
nic" name come from this, there's a development history, thus an *ontogeny*=
.
=C2=A0
Short developments, well, are likely to do only limited changes to=
 the initial phenotype P0, so you might not get
the best out of the optimiz=
ation run. The transformations are encoded as perceptron, with a limited ap=
proximation power, thus you can not expect to have very smart transformatio=
ns doing all the work in a few steps. So to have smarter developments, doin=
g a lot of transformation work on P0, you need long developments. So far so=
 good, as the paper shows, it's what happens in my experiments. Using more =
development steps is the most effective to improve the best fitness of an o=
ptimization run, while using a more expressive transformation G is not very=
 effective (side note: reminds me a bit of Baldwin theory of evolution and =
epigenetic). But long developments also means more computational ressources=
, and those physical simulation ain't cheap. So one might think, let's star=
t with short development, and once the optimization run starts to stagnate,=
 just crank-up the development length. Use long developments for the aggres=
sive optimization part, use short
 development for the beginning of the opt=
imization, where we don;t need that smart development processes to have fit=
ness gain. There's various options to do this, staged development is one.

=
You have to hand-pick an initial phenotype P0, when using an "ontogenic" en=
coding. Usually, it would be some lame-but-working solution for the optimiz=
ation problem. First optimization run, you use your hand-made initial pheno=
type P0. You do a full optimization run, and pick the best phenotype of the=
 whole run, P1+. You run an other optimization run, everything the same, *b=
ut* the initial phenotype you will pick to initiate the development of all =
your genotype will be P1+, not P0. And you can repeat this, once done with =
this optimization run, pick the best phenotype of the whole run, P2+. Use i=
t as the initiate the developments for the 3rd optimization run, etc, etc. =
It works a bit like staged rockets somehow... Every time you add a new stag=
e, use longer developments, use your favorite witchcraft to figure out how =
to choose the development length. I used a geometric progression, doubling =
the number of development steps at each stage. In practice, what
 happened =
was what happened, reaching same level of fitness of a a single run with lo=
ng development, but at a fraction of the computational cost. This staged de=
velopment thingy is very had-hoc and I see it as a mere engineering trick, =
but okay, seems safe to use, can save you computing time, is easy to code, =
so well, why not...


Cheers,
Alex


________________________________

Re : [neat] Any Prior Applications of NEAT In Which The Genotype Itself Is =
The Output?


=C2=A0 


Alex,
I was wondering if you could expand somewhat =
on your paper's staging process referenced in section 5.4? I am attempting =
to distinguish it from Neat's complexification process.
Thanks,
Andy

--- I=
n neat@yahoogroups.com, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> =

> =C3=82=C2=A0If the gradient-based optimizer modify the phenotype, at eac=
h genotype evaluation, yes, I would see this as an iterated transformation.=
 Good example of this would be optimization of a perceptron, for a supervis=
ed learning problem. The genotype would be the structure of perceptron, and=
 some parameters for an initialization heuristic. The initial phenotype wou=
ld be a perceptron decoded from the genotype. Then, the development would b=
e a retro-propagation training of that perceptron. Retro-propagation is a g=
radient-based optimization, using local informations. I'm sure such a thing=
 crossed many minds ^^
> 
> If the gradient-based optimizer modify the geno=
type, no. So if the genotype is directly the weights of a fixed-topology pe=
rceptron, nope.
> 
> I can post my HyperNEAT setup quite soon, and I should=
 have done this since a while, lazy me... I had to do some a bit of enginee=
ring in the code, to make it compilable on the cluster I was using. So alth=
ough it's the genuine original HyperNEAT code, some cosmetic chirurgy happe=
ned. More important, you got the fitness function for the problem. =C3=82=
=C2=A0I just need to write a little bit of documentation on how to compile =
and use the whole mess. I'll post it on my website and send an=C3=82=C2=A0a=
nnouncement=C3=82=C2=A0of this. Can be done within few days.
> 
> Cheers,
>=
 Alex
> 
> ________________________________
> De=C3=82=C2=A0: afcarl2 <afca=

> =C3=82=C2=A0 
> 
> 
> Alex,
> If an individual maps to =
a point evaluation of the design space, and the local jacobian of the fitne=
ss landscape is such that an added local gradient based sub-optimization ta=
sk follows a trajectory resulting in an improved fitness associated w/ an u=
pdated individual, would that satisfy the classification requirements assoc=
iated w/ "implicit evolved embryogeny"? Also, would you consider uploading =
your updated version of Hyperneat used in your study to the group file repo=
sitory?
> Thanks,
> Andy
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Alexandre Devert=
 <marmakoide@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi,
> > =C3=83=E2=80=9A=C3=82=C2=A0 I'm not 1=
00% sure to get the whole meaning of your question, so I might answer a bit=
 off-target ^^
> > 
> > =C3=83=E2=80=9A=C3=82=C2=A0 In that paragraph about=
 the taxonomy (end of page 4), I mention "local information". It's not a gr=
adient, as in "gradient based optimization", that is, a clue on the local g=
eometry of the objective function. By "local information", I mean, *any* ki=
nd of local feedback of the behavior of the phenotype. If we optimize a pla=
ne wing, it could be, say, the local air pressure. If we optimize a heat ex=
changer, it would be local heath flux. If we optimize a water pipe network,=
 it would the local water flux and pressure.
> > 
> > 
> > =C3=83=E2=80=9A=
=C3=82=C2=A0Then, does this local information feeback turns "external non-e=
volved embryogeny" into "implicit evolved embryogeny" ? It's quite a fuzzy =
territory, if you ask me. Let's say you decode the genotype as a transforma=
tion of an initial phenotype to a final one. You have many many ways to do =
this, and you can have genotype as a very flexible transformation (many man=
y development steps, each doing small changes in all possible ways) or a ve=
ry inflexible one (1 single very had-hoc transformation step). So between "=
external non-evolved embryogeny" and "implicit evolved embryogeny", I belie=
ve there is a whole gradient of possibilities rather than a sharp border be=
tween the two. Actually, to have a trully "implicit evolved embryogeny", it=
 would unbounded development. But in practice, allowing a few steps of deve=
lopment brings a lot of flexibility for a genotype, so it's a rethoritical =
remark.
> > 
> > Cheers,
> > 
> > Alex
> > 
> > 
> > ______________________=
__________

<html><body><div style=3D"color:#000; background-color:#fff; font-family:ti=
mes new roman, new york, times, serif;font-size:12pt"><div><span>Hi,</span>=
</div><div><span><br></span></div><div><span>  So staged development o=
f section 5.4 and NEAT complexification. They are very different mechanisms=
, and I think the intentions behind them are also quite different. I'll try=
 to show this clearly. </span>The actual idea of staged development comes f=
rom Federici, check his 2004-2007 papers on cellular automata evolution.<br=
></div><div><span><br></span></div><div><span>NEAT operators can augment th=
e genotype during an optimization run, to make it more expressive. That's a=
 nice side of  encoding functions as neuron network, you can smoothly =
refine them by throwing in more neurons and connections. The intention is, =
rather than starting straight with a big, fixed neuron network to optimize,=
 you start with a small one and get a bigger one little by little. For
 neu=
ron network, the network topology choice is determinant, and NEAT can find =
the network topology for you.</span></div><div><br>With those "ontogenic" e=
ncodings, the genotype =3D> phenotype decoding works as follow. For each=
 genotype you evaluate, you take an initial phenotype P0, always the same f=
or all genotypes. The genotypes are tranformations G applied to phenotypes =
P. So the decoding is simply iterating the transformation encoded by the ge=
notype. For each single genotype Gx, the mapping is P0=3D>P1,x=3D>P2,=
x=3D>...=3D>Pn,x with Pn,x =3D Gx(Pn-1,x) and P0,x=3DP0 I insist, thi=
s is done for each evaluation of a genotype. Of course, you then take Pn,x =
the final phenotype to compute a fitness. The P0=3D>P1,x=3D>P2,x=3D&g=
t;...=3D>Pn,x is called "development" of an individual, as a very loose =
and abstraction from the biology term. I don't pretend to do any biological=
 parallel and don't want to do any, it's not my scope. The "ontogenic" name=
 come from
 this, there's a development history, thus an *ontogeny*.<br>&nb=
sp;<br>Short developments, well, are likely to do only limited changes to t=
he initial phenotype P0, so you might not get<br>the best out of the optimi=
zation run. The transformations are encoded as perceptron, with a limited a=
pproximation power, thus you can not expect to have very smart transformati=
ons doing all the work in a few steps. So to have smarter developments, doi=
ng a lot of transformation work on P0, you need long developments. So far s=
o good, as the paper shows, it's what happens in my experiments. Using more=
 development steps is the most effective to improve the best fitness of an =
optimization run, while using a more expressive transformation G is not ver=
y effective (side note: reminds me a bit of Baldwin theory of evolution and=
 epigenetic). But long developments also means more computational ressource=
s, and those physical simulation ain't cheap. So one might think, let's sta=
rt
 with short development, and once the optimization run starts to stagnat=
e, just crank-up the development length. Use long developments for the aggr=
essive optimization part, use short development for the beginning of the op=
timization, where we don;t need that smart development processes to have fi=
tness gain. There's various options to do this, staged development is one.<=
br><br>You have to hand-pick an initial phenotype P0, when using an "ontoge=
nic" encoding. Usually, it would be some lame-but-working solution for the =
optimization problem. First optimization run, you use your hand-made initia=
l phenotype P0. You do a full optimization run, and pick the best phenotype=
 of the whole run, P1+. You run an other optimization run, everything the s=
ame, *but* the initial phenotype you will pick to initiate the development =
of all your genotype will be P1+, not P0. And you can repeat this, once don=
e with this optimization run, pick the best phenotype of the whole run,
 P2=
+. Use it as the initiate the developments for the 3rd optimization run, et=
c, etc. It works a bit like staged rockets somehow... Every time you add a =
new stage, use longer developments, use your favorite witchcraft to figure =
out how to choose the development length. I used a geometric progression, d=
oubling the number of development steps at each stage. In practice, what ha=
ppened was what happened, reaching same level of fitness of a a single run =
with long development, but at a fraction of the computational cost. This st=
aged development thingy is very had-hoc and I see it as a mere engineering =
trick, but okay, seems safe to use, can save you computing time, is easy to=
 code, so well, why not...<br><br></div><div>Cheers,</div><div>Alex<br></di=
v><div style=3D"font-family: times new roman, new york, times, serif; font-=
size: 12pt;"><div style=3D"font-family: times new roman, new york, times, s=
erif; font-size: 12pt;"><font face=3D"Arial" size=3D"2"><hr

t-weight: bold;">Objet :</span></b> Re: Re : Re : Re : Re : [neat] Any=
 Prior Applications of NEAT In Which The Genotype Itself Is The Output?<br>=

      <div><br>
<br>
Alex,<br>
I was wondering if you could expand =
somewhat on your paper's staging process referenced in section 5.4? I am at=
tempting to distinguish it from Neat's complexification process.<br>
Thanks=
,<br>
Andy<br>
<br>

oogroups.com" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com">neat=
@yahoogroups.com</a>, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@...> wrote:<br>
&g=
t;<br>
> Hi,<br>
> <br>
> =C3=82 If the gradient-based optimi=
zer modify the phenotype, at each genotype evaluation, yes, I would see thi=
s as an iterated transformation. Good example of this would be optimization=
 of a perceptron, for a supervised learning problem. The genotype would be =
the structure of perceptron, and some parameters for an initialization heur=
istic. The initial phenotype would be a perceptron decoded from the genotyp=
e. Then, the development would be a retro-propagation training of that perc=
eptron. Retro-propagation is a gradient-based optimization, using local inf=
ormations. I'm sure such a thing crossed many minds ^^<br>
> <br>
> I=
f the gradient-based optimizer modify the genotype, no. So if the genotype =
is directly the weights of a fixed-topology perceptron, nope.<br>
> <br>=

> I can post my HyperNEAT setup quite soon, and I should have done this=
 since a while, lazy me... I had to do some a bit of engineering in the cod=
e, to make it compilable on the cluster I was using. So although it's the g=
enuine original HyperNEAT code, some cosmetic chirurgy happened. More impor=
tant, you got the fitness function for the problem. =C3=82 I just need=
 to write a little bit of documentation on how to compile and use the whole=
 mess. I'll post it on my website and send an=C3=82 announcement=C3=82=
 of this. Can be done within few days.<br>
> <br>
> Cheers,<br>
=
> Alex<br>
> <br>

> Alex,<br>
> If an individual maps t=
o a point evaluation of the design space, and the local jacobian of the fit=
ness landscape is such that an added local gradient based sub-optimization =
task follows a trajectory resulting in an improved fitness associated w/ an=
 updated individual, would that satisfy the classification requirements ass=
ociated w/ "implicit evolved embryogeny"? Also, would you consider uploadin=
g your updated version of Hyperneat used in your study to the group file re=
pository?<br>
> Thanks,<br>
> Andy<br>

> ><br>
> > Hi,<br>

gt; =C3=83=E2=80=9A=C3=82  I'm not 100% sure to get the whole meaning =
of your question, so I might answer a bit off-target ^^<br>
> > <br>
=
> > =C3=83=E2=80=9A=C3=82  In that paragraph about the taxonomy =
(end of page 4), I mention "local information". It's not a gradient, as in =
"gradient based optimization", that is, a clue on the local geometry of the=
 objective function. By "local information", I mean, *any* kind of local fe=
edback of the behavior of the phenotype. If we optimize a plane wing, it co=
uld be, say, the local air pressure. If we optimize a heat exchanger, it wo=
uld be local heath flux. If we optimize a water pipe network, it would the =
local water flux and pressure.<br>
> > <br>
> > <br>
> > =
=C3=83=E2=80=9A=C3=82 Then, does this local information feeback turns =
"external non-evolved embryogeny" into "implicit evolved embryogeny" ? It's=
 quite a fuzzy territory, if you ask me. Let's say you decode the genotype =
as a transformation of an initial phenotype to a final one. You have many m=
any ways to do this, and you can have genotype as a very flexible transform=
ation (many many development steps, each doing small changes in all possibl=
e ways) or a very inflexible one (1 single very had-hoc transformation step=
). So between "external non-evolved embryogeny" and "implicit evolved embry=
ogeny", I believe there is a whole gradient of possibilities rather than a =
sharp border between the two. Actually, to have a trully "implicit evolved =
embryogeny", it would unbounded development. But in practice, allowing a fe=
w steps of development brings a lot of flexibility for a genotype, so it's =
a rethoritical remark.<br>
> > <br>
> > Cheers,<br>
> > <=
br>
> > Alex<br>
